 < this message is answering to > 
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."

cqs.cq: What if the airlines' frequent schedule changes after passengers have confirmed their flights cause them to incur significant inconveniences, such as missed engagements and excessive travel costs, then shouldn't the airlines be held accountable for reimbursing passengers for these losses?

Do you have any evidence from industry or regulatory sources that supports the claim that airlines are responsible for compensating passengers for schedule changes without prior notice, rather than simply adhering to their standard change policies?

JJMurray_180.input:
JJMurray: "a classic example above.
Don't just ban peanuts,
ban everything that might contain something which may have encountered a peanut or peanut product in it's life.
Once you start a ban on one product, you better be prepared for more and more demands to ban a lot of other items."
 < this message is answering to > 
PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.
Ingestion or contact can trigger severe reactions.
Take peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter (e.g., trail mix, peanut butter crackers) off of airplanes.
This is all the airlines need to do.
Most airlines already have a suitable replacement snack.
Anyone with a severe allergy already has EpiPens or other medications.
Airlines need not provide these.
As an outsider to the airline industry, it is hard for me to say what level of cleaning currently occurs on an aircraft.
Obviously, on quick turnaround layovers, flight crews only have time for a cursory cleaning.
I don't know.
If so, perhaps repeated standard cleanings without further peanut exposure would be sufficient?
The rule probably has the best chance of being enacted if it minimizes overall cost to the airline industry while meeting the desired safety requirements.
Personally, I would be satisfied if the rule simply called for removal of peanuts from aircraft and allowed the airlines to put forth a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets."

cqs.cq: What if the removal of peanuts from airplanes results in a significant increase in the cost of cleaning and sanitizing the aircraft, potentially affecting the airline industry's ability to provide a safe and clean environment for passengers?

If airlines are expected to maintain a certain level of cleanliness to prevent peanut exposure, why would it not be a standard requirement to ensure the removal of all potential peanut allergens, rather than just peanuts themselves?

You don’t pay an interest rate
The interest rate varies by the amount of the charge for the credit but also the time over which you repay it
So if you borrow some money from me, and you pay it back very quickly, the interest rate will be much higher than if you pay it back over a long period
But the amount it costs you is exactly the same"

cqs.cq: Does the potential for higher interest rates on short-term loans offset the supposed benefits of quicker repayment?
Do you have any empirical evidence that supports the claim that the interest rate on a loan varies inversely with the duration of repayment?

If a borrower with a high credit score pays back a loan quickly and is charged a lower interest rate, would a similar principle apply to the economy when a company pays back taxes on a large profit over a long period versus paying it in a single year?
If the interest rate varies based on the time you repay the loan, wouldn't that imply that you're essentially penalizing borrowers for being responsible and paying back their loans more quickly?

JL_5.input:
JL: "Because they’re very short-term loans
if you borrowed £200 from me, and in 30 days time you pay back £250, the interest rate on that is 1,413.01%
It sounds horrendous
...
But if you pay me back the same amount of money in six months time the interest rate is only 57.3%.
And if you take a year to pay it back it goes down"

cqs.cq: What if the drastic decrease in interest rates over longer loan periods causes borrowers to be less likely to default on their loans?
Do you have a financial institution or regulatory body that condones or certifies such extreme interest rates in the UK?
If a loan with an interest rate of 1,413.01% is deemed "horrendous," would a loan with an interest rate of 57.3% not also be considered excessive and exploitative?
Is it morally justifiable that a loan's interest rate can be so drastically reduced with just a simple change in payment term, yet the underlying debt remains the same?

JW_41.input:
JW: "It’s only since the state intervened that people have been uninterested in which bank they put their money in
In the old days of early capitalism, bankers were famously prudent people. And they went to great lengths to advertise how prudent they were.
This stopped not because of the big bang, which liberalised banking, which is what everybody thinks.
It stopped because of government guarantees to depositors."

cqs.cq: What if the government guarantees to depositors caused a loss of prudence among bankers, leading to a decrease in the quality of banking services?
Do you have any historical evidence that demonstrates how the government's guarantees to depositors significantly impacted the behavior of bankers in the early days of capitalism?
Would the same prudent banking practices have been maintained if the government guarantees were to be withdrawn?

If prudent banking practices were indeed a hallmark of pre-liberalized banking, then does the presence of government guarantees actually undermine the very principles of prudent banking that once characterized these institutions?

Javier_84.input:
Javier: "I have no problem requiring the airlines to give notification of any "known" delays within 30 minutes of when they become aware of it.
BUT, being a frequent traveler, I see all sorts of problems which are unavoidable and for which the airlines will be blamed by giving such notice with the intend that some flyers may be able to delay thier trip to the airport or even the departure gate.
I know that many times the airlines can't also know exactly when a weather hold or a maintenance issue will be rectified and that the flight is then ready to go.
Many time it can be surprisingly faster than expected.
The problem is that some flyers may then  wait before going to the airport,
but then find that the problem was rectified sooner than expected and the flight departed.
Of course the flyer and the flyers rights organization will then crucify the airlines for such poor planning.
Flyers need to grow up and quit pouting and blaming everthing on the airlines.
They can't have it both ways."

cqs.cq: What if the requirement to notify delays within 30 minutes causes airlines to err on the side of caution, potentially resulting in unnecessary flight delays that ultimately affect the passenger's travel experience?
Do you believe that airlines should be held accountable for their operational challenges and uncertainties, rather than solely relying on passenger expectations of instantaneous delay notifications?
If airlines are expected to provide timely notifications for unavoidable delays, should passengers also be held accountable for not being able to adjust their plans accordingly?

If airlines are required to provide timely notifications for delays, does that not also imply a responsibility to take steps to prevent or minimize those delays, rather than simply shifting the burden onto passengers?

JetJock_156_1.input:
JetJock: "Yes, most airlines pay flight crew members scheduled flight time or actual time away from the gate whichever is more.
Eg. if a flight is scheduled for 2 hours "block to block" (from/to the gate) but it takes 3 to fly it, the crew gets 3.
If the flight leaves that gate and returns 2.5 hours later, most airlines only pay that crew either the 2.0 scheduled (if it cancels) or much less.
For most crewmembers, the notion that 1 hour at the gate, 2.5 hours of sitting on that taxiway and only get paid for 2 is not very palatable.
Whereas sitting for 2.5 hours then fly 2 totals 4.5.
It is mostly the pay structure of pilots/flight attendants that poorly designed.
Most people would balk at the notion of working 4.5 hours and getting paid for 2.
The ground delay limitation, has, well, it's limitations."

cqs.cq: What if the pay structure that rewards pilots and flight attendants for actual flight time rather than scheduled time away from the gate causes them to be more likely to accept ground delays and reduce overall operational efficiency?
Can you provide a specific example of a major airline that has successfully implemented a pay structure that incentivizes flight crew members for actual flight time, rather than just scheduled time?

If airlines pay crew members for the actual time spent flying versus the scheduled time, why would they not consider the actual time spent waiting on the taxiway or at the gate as part of their overall working hours?
If airlines compensate flight crew members for their actual flight time, why do they still penalize them for ground delays, effectively reducing their pay?

JetJock_156_2.input:
JetJock: "If we were in preregulation days where an airline was making money with only 60% of the seats filled, flights canceling due to the 3 hour limit would not be much of a problem.
What is a problem is flights that are now being canceled because of the new rule
and virtually no seats available on subsequent flights to accommodate those passengers.
If the ground delays are due to ATC, weather, VIP movement (president in the area) then passengers will not be, as a rule, given cancellation perks since they are beyond the control of the company.
If the air conditioning, and restrooms are functioning properly and there are plenty of beverages and snacks on board then that maximum number of hours should be flexible.
I would be curious to hear from people that had their flight cancel due to the 3 hour limit and how the airlines handled them after that.
My guess this rule will cause greater damage to air travel then the occasional extended ground hold on an airplane with poor air conditioning or nonfunctioning lavatories.
if the airplane is comfortable and exceeding the 3 hour limit would cancel the flight with no hotel or meal compensation, would exceeding the 3 hours be ok and if so what would be a reasonable number above 3 be?"

cqs.cq: What if the 3-hour limit rule causes a surge in flight cancellations due to overbooked flights, leading to significant customer dissatisfaction, and would this ultimately affect the airline's long-term profitability and public trust?

Do you have any evidence that the 3-hour limit for flight cancellations, which you seem to consider a reasonable threshold, is grounded in scientific research or industry best practices, rather than arbitrary airline policies?

If an airline can cancel a flight due to a 3-hour ground delay and not provide compensation, would it not be reasonable for passengers to expect similar treatment when flights are canceled due to the 3-hour limit in the air?

If the airline is allowed to cancel flights due to the 3 hour limit, why should they be held accountable for providing compensation to passengers if the delays are caused by factors outside their control?

KHenrickson_172.input:
KHenrickson: "The notification isn't so much a problem at most airports.
The electronic boards are usually updated minute by minute.
The problem is that the airlines will say "Flight 100, delayed till 7:00pm." then "Flight 100, delayed till 7:05pm".  And so on and so forth.
They're notifying everyone...with completely useless information.
Forcing them to do so more frequently isn't going to fix a thing.
Forcing them to come up with an accurate estimate is what is needed."

cqs.cq: Does the constant updating of flight delay times by the airlines ultimately cause more confusion and frustration among passengers rather than providing them with accurate and reliable information?
Do you have any empirical evidence to support the claim that minute-by-minute updates are the most effective way to manage passenger expectations and mitigate delays in flight schedules?
If airlines can provide minute-by-minute updates, why can't they provide accurate and reliable estimates for flight delays instead of constantly changing the expected departure time?
If the airlines are constantly updating minute-by-minute flight information, does this not serve as a sufficient effort to address the issue of delayed flight notifications?

MP_22.input:
MP: "Well, you say the banks are the lenders
there are lots of other people who are lenders too
I mean everyone who puts money into a bank, or a building society, is putting it there so that the bank can lend it on
I mean you just heard Simon Rose say
there’s been 100 billion pounds transfer from savers to borrowers
So if you're going to raise your banner for anybody who’s doing badly in this situation, I would have thought you might have raised it for savers, in the first instance"

cqs.cq: If the banks are indeed just facilitators of lending, then why do they hold the majority of the power and influence in this process, rather than the individuals who are the actual lenders?
Does the MP's assertion that savers should be prioritized over borrowers in this context align with the fundamental principles of banking, where lending is a core function of the institution?
If banks are seen as the primary lenders, wouldn't the savers, who are essentially the primary depositors, also be considered the primary investors?
If the MP is highlighting the plight of savers, shouldn't he also advocate for policies that directly benefit them, rather than solely criticizing banks?

MP_48.input:
MP: "	I think it’s very interesting that capitalism is coming under such a lot of attack here
And I don’t say that’s inappropriate
But we haven’t yet attacked democracy
I mean one of the things that strikes me about this is that when you have incumbent governments, and they see that consumer credit boom mushrooming and mushrooming, what do they do?
They don’t want to stop it
They don’t want to stop it, because they want voters.
They want voters who feel artificially rich
because voters who feel artificially rich will probably vote for the incumbent"

cqs.cq: Does the desire for voter loyalty from artificially wealthy citizens lead to policymakers prioritizing economic growth over potential long-term consequences?
Do you have any empirical evidence that supports the claim that voters who feel artificially rich are more likely to vote for incumbent governments, rather than a theoretical assumption?
If the government's desire to maintain consumer credit is seen as a means to artificially enrich voters, does this not also imply a tacit endorsement of economic systems that perpetuate inequality?
If politicians are more concerned with maintaining power than addressing the systemic issues of consumer credit, does that not undermine the democratic principles they claim to represent?

MR_TELEVOID__178.input:
MR: "Maybe you're just the only one who gives a shit about their hair"
 < this message is answering to > 
XxEnder: "Am I the only one who noticed that Bernie combed his hair"

cqs.cq: What if the fact that Bernie's hair being combed affects how others perceive his authority and leadership?
Do you have a factual basis to support the claim that you're the only one who gives a shit about Bernie's hair?
If a politician combs his hair to fit societal norms, why should a person of color not be able to express themselves through similar cultural and natural hair practices?
Doesn't everyone else in the room have the right to notice and express their opinions about Bernie's hair as much as you do?

MT_10.input:
MT: "we know from lots and lots of research, you know this, that people aren’t very good at understanding financial products
And they're easily seduced into acting, in the short-term, in ways which aren’t very good for them in the long-term
Doesn’t the history of the financial services industry demonstrate that this is an industry with a deep commitment to exploiting those weaknesses, in order to make a fast buck?"

cqs.cq: Doesn't the exploitation of consumer weaknesses by the financial services industry contribute to the widespread financial instability and poor long-term outcomes for individuals?
Does the industry's history of exploiting consumer weaknesses, as you've described, not inherently undermine the notion that its primary focus is profit over customer welfare?

Does the long history of the financial services industry's exploitation of consumer weaknesses demonstrate a parallel to the broader societal patterns of economic inequality and systemic disadvantage?
If the financial services industry is exploiting consumer weaknesses for profit, does that justify its prioritization over consumer protection and long-term well-being?

MT_40.input:
MT: "I don’t think you just said the opposite of them was neutral
So if they're virtues, doesn’t that imply that the opposite of thrift and prudence is immoral?
But, hold on
Isn’t it simply the case that buying a cup of coffee is something which is substantially less demanding than working up a long-term interest rate?
Therefore isn’t it a reasonable thing for the state to intervene in those cases
because the knowledge is bounded?"

cqs.cq: Doesn't the state's intervention in buying a cup of coffee, rather than a long-term interest rate, undermine the principles of thrift and prudence it's supposed to be protecting?

Do you have a philosophical or economic framework that supports the notion that the state should intervene in personal financial decisions, such as buying a cup of coffee, without a clear precedent in democratic or economic literature?

If moral virtues like thrift and prudence can be used to justify state intervention, doesn't that imply that virtues like leisure or pleasure could also be used to justify similar forms of state intervention?
If virtues like thrift and prudence are morally desirable, then isn't it contradictory that their opposites, such as excessive spending and recklessness, aren't also considered immoral?

Melanie_64.input:
Melanie: "Well the State has taken a moral position
that position was non-judgmentalism
and terrible harm it’s done
It’s created a lot of victims who now need help themselves, and who sometimes go on to create other victims through crime
 I think they do need help
but that help should be very carefully calibrated, to restore the capacity for independence and personal responsibility"

cqs.cq: What if the State's non-judgmental approach causes a lack of accountability among those who commit crimes, thus affecting the overall safety and well-being of the community?

Do you have any empirical evidence to support the claim that the State's non-judgmentalism has directly led to an increase in victimization and crime, rather than a more nuanced understanding of the complex factors contributing to these issues?
Does the State's moral position of non-judgmentalism not risk undermining the accountability and personal responsibility that Melanie claims it aims to restore?

If the State's non-judgmentalism stance prioritizes rehabilitation over punishment, shouldn't it also acknowledge the inherent responsibility of those who create victims, rather than solely focusing on providing help to the victims?

Mpogoda_184.input:
Mpogoda: "As a frequent traveler, I would welcome the rule requiring 24 hour refundability of fares + all fees.
Additionally, there should be a certain window,
say, 3 days prior to flying where you should be able to cancel your flight without penalty and receive a refund or at least the ability to change your itinerary without fee.
As I always say to all who will listen,
the airline model is one of the worst business models I know of:
treat your customers with disdain and make it as inconvenient as possible for them to use your product.
Whether it be added fees to check luggage
making it too costly to change your itinerary;
making it virtually impossible to easily use frequent flyer miles or charging an exorbitant amount to actually use them;
not getting timely notice when there are delays to flights
or, even worse, when a flight has been canceled;
and lastly, being treated like cattle at the airport and on the plane."

cqs.cq: What if airlines' restrictive refund and cancellation policies cause consumers to feel undervalued and mistrustful of their business model, ultimately affecting their loyalty and willingness to choose their services?
Do you have any empirical data to support the claim that airlines are consistently prioritizing customer convenience over profits to the extent that you assert?
If airlines treat customers with disdain and make it inconvenient for them to use their product, would it not be a reflection of the broader societal disregard for customer needs and rights?

If airlines prioritize customer satisfaction, why do they not offer a more generous refund and rebooking window, considering the significant stress and financial burden that flight cancellations and delays can cause?

MrFordization__82.input:
MrFordization: "Pentagon classifies global warming as a national security threat
Maybe he just knows more than you"

cqs.cq: What if the Pentagon's classification of global warming as a national security threat causes a shift in military resource allocation, which in turn affects the overall military preparedness and readiness to respond to other potential threats?
Can you provide any credible sources that support the Pentagon's classification of global warming as a national security threat, beyond Mr. Ford's personal assertion?

If Mr. Ford's classification of global warming as a national security threat is seen as a valid concern, would the Pentagon's acknowledgment of climate change's devastating impact on global stability not imply a moral obligation to prioritize immediate action over fossil fuel interests?
If the Pentagon classifies global warming as a national security threat, does this imply that the military is more prepared to address it than the current government?

Mulder_112.input:
Mulder: "Your argument is a strawman.
Nobody is advocating funerals;
you're just trying to deflect attention away from the issue,
which is that there is no real risk to peanut allergy sufferers.
And there is no scientific evidence to support your argument.
You can't even cite the studies you claim exist,
because they don't exist.
The only mean spirited people are those like yourself, who want to trample the rights of the majority for a nonexistent risk that affects a very small number of people.
This has nothing to do with the founding of the U.S. at all."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of scientific evidence to support your argument causes the public to question the legitimacy of your claims and affect the perception of your stance?

Do you have any peer-reviewed studies or scientific evidence that support the claim that the rights of a small minority should be limited due to a perceived risk that is not supported by empirical data?

If you're so concerned about deflecting attention from a perceived risk, why is your response not seen as deflecting attention from the systemic issues of health disparities and food labeling laws that affect the majority, rather than the rights of a small number of people with peanut allergies?
If you can't cite any studies to support your argument, doesn't that undermine the credibility of your claims about a supposed risk to peanut allergy sufferers?

Mulder_226.input:
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."
 < this message is answering to > 
Samsmom: "I am utterly amazed at the ignorance displayed by some of those commenting here.
Allergies are not "perceived"
as Mulder suggests,
and it is ridiculous and unrealistic  to suggest that people with severe food allergies "live in a bubble".
No one who has an allergy chooses to be in this situation,
and walking onto an airplane where peanuts either are being consumed or have been consumed is like playing Russian Roulette.
We are talking about a SNACK ON AN AIRPLANE.
Can you really be complaining about your rights to eat a snack?!?
My son could DIE because you can't forgo a snack for two hours.
While we could drive everywhere we need to go for the rest of his life,
there may come a time when time constraints force us to fly.
No matter how much "responsibility we take", we cannot sufficiently protect him if people around us are eating any peanut product.
We always carry an epipen,
and feel that should be our responsibility.
But, again, that may not be enough to save his life.
Those autoinjectors can only buy us 1015 minutes,
barely enough time for a plane to request an emergency landing site.
He would be dead before we taxied to the gate.
FOR A SNACK!!
An outright ban should be in place."

cqs.cq: Would the potential risk of anaphylactic shock from peanut exposure on an airplane be a sufficient cause for implementing a blanket ban on peanuts in-flight, considering the availability of epipens and the relatively low frequency of reported incidents?

Do you have any scientific evidence or expert opinion supporting the claim that the risk of anaphylactic shock from peanut exposure on an airplane is sufficient to warrant a complete ban on peanut snacks, rather than advocating for more effective allergy management and emergency preparedness measures?

If one's child's life is considered worth the risk of a snack on an airplane, why would not the same level of accommodation be given to those who require a safe environment due to a legitimate allergy?

If your child's life is at such significant risk from peanut exposure, why are you more concerned about the snack options of others than taking measures to ensure your child's safety through vaccination or other medical treatments?

Mulder_240.input:
Mulder: "You're the one who seems to be partisan.
Instead of thinking logically about it, you try to deflect blame for your misguided apprehension onto others by insinuating they have a compulsion.
Serving and eating peanuts is not a public health menace,
so you need to get over it.
Instead of conflating the possible with the inevitable, you should focus on the reality, which is that the possibility is extremely small.
You're more likely to die from getting hit by a car crossing the street, yet you're not advocating we ban driving.
That's being a hypocrite."
 < this message is answering to > 
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."

cqs.cq: Can a blanket assumption that all peanut advocates have an addiction or disorder be cause for the drastic measure of banning peanuts on airplanes?
Do you have any credible scientific evidence to support the claim that peanut consumption on airplanes constitutes a public health menace comparable to tobacco smoking?
Does the logic that driving is a public health menace, therefore it should be banned, mirror the logic that serving peanuts on airplanes is a public health menace, thus it should be discontinued?

Does the argument that serving/eating peanuts on airplanes is a public health menace and should be discontinued equally apply to the advocacy of a peanut-free environment, considering the comparability of the risk factors?

ND_28.input:
ND: "In some ways I agree with you
If you want the economy to run smoothly, you have to incentivise certain types of behaviour.
So, for example in South Korea, in terms of how South Korean grew, it did incentivise saving, at certain times, by certain economic policies
On the other hand, I think what people don’t realise, or only half realise, is the fact that we have actually written off massive amounts of debt
But it certainly isn’t the debts of the people who most need it in society
For productive investments. I agree with you."

cqs.cq: What if incentivizing certain behaviors, such as saving, does not ultimately lead to a more equitable distribution of economic benefits, thereby causing a widening of the wealth gap?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that incentivizing certain behaviors through economic policies is a universally effective strategy for achieving economic growth?
If the South Korean economy incentivized saving through policies, why would a similar approach not be considered for addressing the debt of the most vulnerable individuals in society?

If economic policies that incentivize certain behaviors can be beneficial, can the same logic justify incentivizing destructive behaviors, such as accumulating debt, by ignoring the needs of those most in need?

NYCMuscleman18_161.input:
NYCMuscleman18: "I know this sounds silly,
but I think I shouldn't be charged as much to check a bag as the 250lb man sitting next to me.
I don't mind getting weighed in public...
I don't know.
This is just something that seems unfair to lots of passengers,
and that probably won't get changed without regulation.
At the very least, DOT should make clear to airlines that they can discriminate on the basis of weight without fearing regulatory action."

cqs.cq: Does the potential economic savings from charging heavier passengers more for airline services outweigh the potential negative impact on passenger morale and the potential social implications of weight-based pricing?
Do you have any scientific studies or data to support the claim that weight-based discrimination in airline baggage fees is a significant enough concern to warrant regulatory intervention?

If airline passengers can be charged more for checked bags based on their weight, why would it not be fair to charge passengers based on their weight, rather than their age, ethnicity, or other characteristics?
If airlines can discriminate based on weight without fear of regulatory action, then why should passengers who carry a 250lb bag be charged the same as passengers who carry a standard bag?

NYCMuscleman18_187.input:
NYCMuscleman18: "Agreed.
The most frustrating thing about airline travel is the lack of space.
I don't see why they care so much about letting people game the bumping system, but not at all about personal space.
I guess the big question is, what's DOT's job, exactly?
Is this about inair convenience?
Avoiding pricegouging?
Or something else?"
 < this message is answering to > 
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: Does the airline's prioritization of in-flight convenience over passenger space and comfort cause a significant increase in the risk of health issues such as deep vein thrombosis among passengers?

Do you have any empirical evidence or data that supports the claim that airline carriers have a significant impact on passenger health due to seat size and configuration, or is this assertion primarily anecdotal?
If airlines prioritize in-flight safety by requiring passengers to perform exercises to prevent deep vein thrombosis, why do they not provide the necessary space to accommodate these exercises?

If the airline industry is prioritizing customer convenience and safety, why should passengers be charged exorbitant fees for carrying pets onboard, while airline employees are not held accountable for providing adequate space to prevent deep vein thrombosis?

PeanutAllergy_232.input:
PeanutAllergy: "My son is allergic to peanuts.
The last time we flew on an airline that served peanuts (Southwest) we called ahead and requested that no peanuts be served on our flight.
The airline was extremely accommodating, but there were peanuts on the floor and between the seats from earlier flights.
For that reason, I don't see banning peanuts on specific flights or a peanutfree buffer zone as real solutions.
We now only fly airlines that don't serve peanuts.
We're okay with Snickers because the peanuts are less likely to get spilled.
However, this wouldn't be a good solution for those with an inhalation allergy.
Maybe the ban could extend to all foods when there is a specific request."

cqs.cq: Would the presence of peanuts on flights, even in small quantities, cause a significant enough risk to justify banning peanuts on all flights or creating a peanut-free buffer zone?

Do you think it is reasonable to expect airlines to implement a peanut-free policy on every flight when a single passenger requests it, considering the potential for cross-contamination and the varying severity of peanut allergies?
If airlines can accommodate peanut-free meals on request, why can't they also provide a peanut-free zone or ban peanuts on flights altogether for passengers with severe allergies?
If airlines can be so accommodating to accommodate peanut allergies, why can't they also go the extra mile to ensure a peanut-free environment for passengers with allergies?

PracticalJo_179_1.input:
PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.
Ingestion or contact can trigger severe reactions.
Take peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter (e.g., trail mix, peanut butter crackers) off of airplanes.
This is all the airlines need to do.
Most airlines already have a suitable replacement snack."

cqs.cq: What if the continued presence of peanuts on planes causes severe reactions in passengers, ultimately affecting their overall health and well-being?

Do you have any scientific evidence or expert opinion that supports the claim that the removal of peanuts from planes is more critical than addressing the underlying health concerns of passengers who may have allergies or severe reactions to peanuts?

If peanuts pose a health risk to passengers due to the potential for crumbs, whole peanuts, and residue to be scattered throughout the cabin, would removing them from flights not be a more effective safety measure than simply replacing them with other snacks?
If peanuts are indeed a safety concern on planes, why would airlines not be required to remove all food items containing peanuts, rather than just peanuts themselves?

PracticalJo_179_2.input:
PracticalJo: "Anyone with a severe allergy already has EpiPens or other medications.
Airlines need not provide these.
As an outsider to the airline industry, it is hard for me to say what level of cleaning currently occurs on an aircraft.
Obviously, on quick turnaround layovers, flight crews only have time for a cursory cleaning.
I don't know.
If so, perhaps repeated standard cleanings without further peanut exposure would be sufficient?
The rule probably has the best chance of being enacted if it minimizes overall cost to the airline industry while meeting the desired safety requirements.
Personally, I would be satisfied if the rule simply called for removal of peanuts from aircraft and allowed the airlines to put forth a good faith effort at cleaning their fleets."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of any of the pieces influence the decisions they make about whether to create the digital widget or which digital widget to create?

Do you have any evidence from the Federal Aviation Administration or a reputable industry publication that suggests the current level of cleaning on aircraft is sufficient to prevent peanut exposure for passengers with severe allergies?
If the airline industry can afford to provide EpiPens for passengers with severe allergies, why can't they also be required to implement more thorough cleaning procedures to minimize peanut exposure?
If airlines can't guarantee a completely clean environment, should they still be held accountable for not providing EpiPens for passengers with severe allergies?

Qubbin_80.input:
Qubbin: "I generally support the idea,
but it should be limited only to those fees which are variable,
They should not be allowed to list fees separately that are part of a ticket fee for every ticket issued,
This process serves no purpose other than to show a lower base fee.
That is misleading and meaningless.
If they want to show these components of a ticket, so be it,
but not to suggest a price which could never be exercised."

cqs.cq: What if the practice of listing separate fees for components of a ticket fee leads to consumers misinterpreting the true cost of the ticket, ultimately affecting their purchasing decisions?
Do you have a legal precedent or industry standard that supports the claim that ticket fees can be broken down into separate components, rather than being considered as a single base fee?
If ticket components are simply listed as separate fees, would that not make the total price of the ticket more transparent and honest, rather than misleading with a lower base fee?
If he can justify a variable fee, does that not imply that the actual price of the ticket is higher than the listed base fee?

SWong_118_1.input:
SWong: "My son is severely allergic to peanuts and has allergic reactions as a result of being around people eating peanuts due to the peanut dust in the air.
We had to travel internationally and were able to work with the airline to book peanut free roundtrip flights after submitting a letter from my son's allergist.
The airline did everything they could including serving snacks without peanuts, putting allergy alert stickers on our seats, and making an announcement asking passengers to refrain from eating their peanut snacks.
My son was fine going to our destination but had an allergic reaction within minutes of being seated for our return trip.
Since he didn't eat any peanuts, we gave him some benadryl, moved him to a different row, and wiped down his new seat.
We were fortunate that his reaction was not severe enough to require an epipen injection and a trip to the hospital in another country."

cqs.cq: What if the airline's efforts to accommodate my son's peanut allergy were ineffective in preventing his allergic reaction, would that indicate a need for more comprehensive and standardized allergy protocols in air travel?

Do you believe that airlines' efforts to accommodate passengers with severe food allergies, such as providing peanut-free flights and allergy alert stickers, are sufficient to prevent all potential allergic reactions, or are additional measures necessary to ensure passenger safety?
If airlines can go to great lengths to accommodate a child's peanut allergy, why can't schools and workplaces take similar precautions for students and employees with life-threatening food allergies?
If airlines took such precautions to accommodate a child's peanut allergy, why did the airline not take more proactive measures to prevent the allergic reaction from occurring in the first place?

SWong_118_2.input:
SWong: "We suspect that he was reacting to peanut residue in the area of his seat from the previous flight.
We may not be so lucky next time because we have been told that the next reaction is even stronger than the last.
Even though we were on a peanutfree fight, my son still was not safe because of the peanut residue on the plane from a previous flight.
If peanuts are banned on all flights, my son would have been safe.
When an allergic reaction occurs high up in the sky over a huge ocean, and an epipen injection can only give a person an extra 20 minutes, there is not enough time to turn the plane around and take the person to the hospital.
I believe that it is reasonable to ban peanuts from airline flights if that assures the safety of a passenger that has a severe peanut allergy.
This decision could mean life or death for someone."

cqs.cq: What if banning peanuts on flights would cause a significant increase in flight costs, which would then affect the airline industry's bottom line and potentially lead to reduced safety measures?

Do you have any data or research that supports the claim that banning peanuts from airline flights would be more effective in preventing anaphylactic reactions than educating flight attendants on proper allergy protocols and emergency response procedures?

If a passenger with a severe peanut allergy is at risk of death due to a delayed medical response at high altitudes, why should airlines not prioritize the safety of that individual by banning peanuts from flights, rather than relying on an epipen injection as a sole solution?
If banning peanuts from flights could save a life, would the risks associated with implementing such a ban outweigh the benefits?

Sithsaber__198.input:
Sithsaber: "Have you been to high school
It's shit"
 < this message is answering to > 
g: "high school is high school, college is college"

cqs.cq: What if the lack of education, as represented by the dismissive tone towards high school, influences their views on the value of education and thus affects their future decision-making?
Do you have any personal experience or academic credentials that qualify you to diminish the value of someone's educational background?

If high school is indeed "high school," then wouldn't that imply that the term "high school" is universally understood, much like how the term "high school" is universally understood, regardless of the speaker's age or generation?

If you consider high school and college as distinct educational levels, then why do you use the same dismissive tone to describe both, suggesting that you may not value the educational differences between them?

SofieM_128.input:
SofieM: "Keep in mind that you wouldn't be able to get out of the plane if it were in the air, either.
I think deplaning is a bit extreme,
because it could throw an already imbalanced flight schedule out of whack, and might delay flights even further or lead to cancellation.
I sat on a tarmac in London for five hours earlier this year, but I'd rather wait it out than hop off the plane and miss an opportunity to take off.
However, I see no problem with regular passenger updates on the progress of the delay."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of transparency and communication about flight delays, like the one SofieM experienced, causes more anxiety and stress for passengers?
Do you believe the potential risks of deplaning, such as delayed flights or cancellations, outweigh the benefits of receiving regular passenger updates on flight progress?
If passengers are allowed to deplane and wait on the ground, wouldn't the airline then be responsible for providing accommodations and compensation for the extended delay?
If deplaning is indeed an extreme measure, then should airlines prioritize the comfort of passengers over the potential inconvenience caused by flight delays?

SofieM_73.input:
SofieM: "the DOT got the idea of flight notifications from the airlines themselves,
so I wouldn't be so quick to discount the incentive that customer satisfaction plays to airlines.
Here is an excerpt from the proposed rule:
"Carriers recognize the importance of timely and accurate flight information, as evidenced by the fact that many of the largest U.S. carriers promise through their customer service plans to provide passengers all known information about delays and cancellations as soon as they become aware of the issue" (48).
Any business which intends to survive has to satisfy its customers, otherwise the customers will simply stop buying their product, and the business will go bankrupt. Airlines themselves already thought up flight status notifications because there was customer demand for them.
I find it interesting that you claim neither passengers nor profits to be benefiting from the current state of air transit affairs.
Now, air fare is affordable (prices of air fares have decreased 25% since 1991) and more available to citizens than ever before.
Airlines like Southwest are benefiting exactly because they are offering low fares, serving their customer needs, which would seem to disprove your statement that both profits and passengers suffer in the status quo."

cqs.cq: Does the airlines' decision to offer flight status notifications, driven by customer demand, not inherently suggest that passenger satisfaction and airline profits are not mutually exclusive, but rather interconnected?
Do you have a scientific source or empirical evidence that supports your claim that both passengers and profits suffer equally in the current state of air transit affairs?

If airlines like Southwest are indeed benefiting from their customer-centric approach, why would the proposed rule, which is largely driven by customer demand, not be seen as a positive development for both passengers and airlines?
If airlines already cater to customer demand by providing timely flight information, how can you claim that passengers and profits are suffering equally in the current state of air transit affairs?

SofieM_8.input:
SofieM: "In general, I think that blanket policies on this topic would be a bad idea,
because people have varying capacities to handle travel.
For example, the first time I ever flew without a parent (13 years ago), I was 7 years old, and I went with my older brother who was 10.
We flew from Chicago to Colorado with no incident.
However, that doesn't mean that every 7 or 10 year old can handle itmany can't, and shouldn't try.
It's something that the parents themselves should decide,
because they know their children better than the airlines do.
Also, be careful when talking about "minors" flying alone on airplanes.
I didn't turn 18 until I was already a sophomore in college
Different airlines will treat this issue differently.
Applying a blanket policy will take away the options that come in an open marketplace of ideas.
If I only had one option, because every airline was required to treat "minors" in the same manner, my travel choices would have been limited, not expanded."

cqs.cq: What if a blanket policy that prohibits minors from flying alone would cause parents to have less control over their children's travel experiences?

Do you have any evidence from scientific research or expert opinion that supports the notion that parents' individual assessments of their children's readiness for solo air travel are more reliable than airline-imposed blanket policies?
If airlines can accommodate children flying with varying levels of parental supervision, why can't they also adapt to accommodate children flying alone with varying levels of maturity and readiness?
If blanket policies on minors flying alone are indeed a bad idea, then wouldn't a one-size-fits-all approach to gun ownership also be detrimental to individual freedoms?

TRUMP_101.input:
TRUMP: "It 's not negotiable , no
Let her release the e-mails
Why did she delete 33,000"

cqs.cq: What if the deletion of 33,000 emails by Hillary Clinton causes a lack of transparency and accountability in her presidential campaign?
Do you have any evidence that supports the claim that deleting 33,000 emails is a more significant issue than the content of those emails, in the context of your presidency?
If Trump's demand for Clinton to release emails is a non-negotiable issue, why is the public's access to Trump's tax returns and potential conflicts of interest considered negotiable?
If the emails were so crucial to the investigation, why did Trump's decision to not make them public seem more about avoiding accountability than about upholding transparency?

dberger_74_1.input:
dberger: "There must be a complete ban on tree nuts and peanuts on planes.
It is a closed space.
I am allergic to peanuts and almonds
and I am impacted every time I fly.
A nut free zone does not work
since the dust from nuts gets in the closed air system of the plane.
For the time that people are on planes there should be consideration of others who have no control as to the reactions they have to nuts.
For almost all other foods the allergy only occurs if the food is ingested
so you can easily avoid the allergic reaction but not eating the food.
This is not true for many of us with nut allergies
we react if other people are eating the food
since it is an airborne allergy.
I do fly but I have to take multiple Benadryl pills every 4 hours to keep from reacting to the airborne dust of the nuts.
This works for now
but I always wonder when it will no longer be enough.
An epipen is not the answer
as it lasts only look enough for the plane to land
which is not a practical solution when you are flying on a long flight over water
and would certainly be a much greater inconvenience to the other passengers than a ban on nut products on planes if the plane was able to land.
The rules airlines have are ridiculous
Southwest is not nut free
they will not serve nuts
but if you fly a late flight the peanuts are all over the floor and seats.
Some other airlines have the rows around you 'nut free'
but advise you they can do nothing if the person seated next to you brings nuts on and wants to eat them."

cqs.cq: What if the presence of tree nuts and peanuts on planes causes severe allergic reactions for some passengers, yet airlines prioritize the convenience of serving these products over accommodating the needs of individuals with airborne allergies?

Do you have any scientific evidence or expert opinion that supports the claim that the presence of tree nuts and peanuts on planes poses a significant risk to the health of individuals with allergies when they are not ingested, rather than being a concern of airborne exposure?

If the airline industry requires passengers to accommodate individuals with nut allergies by designating nut-free zones, why should they not also take similar precautions to address the needs of passengers with other in-flight allergies, such as those to strong scents or chemicals, by designating scent-free or chemical-free zones?

If airlines are responsible for creating a safe environment for passengers, then why should they not take more comprehensive measures to prevent airborne allergens like peanuts and tree nuts from affecting passengers like you who have no control over their reactions?

dberger_74_2.input:
dberger: "Other airlines with advance notice will not serve nuts
but all airlines allow passengers to bring on foods including nuts
and will not stop the person from eating them if they wish to.
So you can have a 'nut free' flight and the person sitting next to you can take out their package of peanuts and eat away
and the airlines will do nothing to help you.
Again all nuts should be banned from airplanes unless it is your own private plane  then go ahead and eat what you want."

cqs.cq: Would allowing passengers to bring and eat nuts on flights, despite the presence of 'nut-free' options, not cause a higher risk of in-flight nut-related allergic reactions?

Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that allowing passengers to bring and consume nuts on flights is a more significant health risk than the airline's own staff consuming nuts in the cabin?
If airlines can accommodate and permit passengers to bring and consume their own food, why should they not also accommodate and permit passengers to bring and consume their own peanuts?

If airlines can't prevent passengers from eating nuts on flights, shouldn't they also be responsible for ensuring the safety of passengers with severe nut allergies, rather than leaving it up to the individuals to self-regulate?

dlpoole_223_1.input:
dlpoole: "Bumping compensation should apply to all carriers
because of the increasing use of regional carriers to serve smaller markets
and their no lesser disruptiveness and potential expense to the traveler.
Passengers may lack check cashing privileges away from their home airport, yet face unplanned and likely elevated expenses after being "bumped."
They should have a mandatory option of cash payment.
An credit card credit, if immediate, would be more secure and as useful to more passengers than either a check or cash.
The proposed compensation limits are too low to provide an incentive to the airlines to limit overbooking
and may be arbitrarily unfair to certain travelers.
The Wall Street Journal recently reproposed a 1977 proposal by the late economist Julian Simon of an auction that would offer bumped passengers a gradually rising reward for giving up their seat.
The arguments are rather compelling.
See the WSJ, June 8, 2010, "Auctions for Overbooking"  or"

cqs.cq: What if the mandatory cash payment option and the proposed auction system by Julian Simon would cause airlines to overbook less frequently, thus affecting the overall passenger experience?

Do you have any empirical evidence to support the claim that the Wall Street Journal's 2010 proposal, suggesting an auction system for bumped passengers, would be more effective in incentivizing airlines to limit overbooking than the current proposed compensation limits?

If airlines can profit from selling a passenger's seat through auctions, why should they not be incentivized to compensate passengers directly through a credit card option rather than limiting the proposed compensation to a fixed amount?

If airlines can profit from overbooking and bumped passengers face significant expenses, why should they not be required to offer a more substantial and standardized compensation option, such as a credit card credit, to mitigate the financial burden on travelers?

dlpoole_223_2.input:
dlpoole: "http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703303904575293011757655060.html
The airlines will overbook so as to optimize their financial results under any given set of caps,
so some passengers will still be involuntarily denied boarding on overbooked flights.
An auction will more accurately price the delay
and the sellers (the delayed passenger(s)) will be left with no complaint that it was involuntary.
An auction would also force the carriers to face the cost of overbooking in customer dissatisfaction and better inform their flight scheduling decisions.
I recall hearing seats being auctioned by progressive increases in the promised compensation by gate agents,
but that was long, long ago and under far greater seat availability and lower probabilities of cascading delays and subsequent denials of boarding for those who took the compensation.
Those procedures were surely regulated by DOT,
(perhaps when the industry was more heavily regulated,)
so perhaps those earlier rules should be revisited."

cqs.cq: What if the airlines' overbooking practices cause a significant increase in passenger dissatisfaction, which in turn affects the airline's long-term financial performance and customer loyalty?
Do you have any empirical evidence from the WSJ article or industry studies to support the claim that auctioning seats would more accurately price the delay and reduce customer dissatisfaction?

If the airline industry can auction off the right to board flights to those who are willing to pay a premium, would this not create a market where passengers are essentially bidding on the right to be treated unfairly?

If the airlines' auction system is more accurate in pricing delay and compensation, then why should the passengers who are involuntarily denied boarding still be forced to accept a fixed, potentially inadequate, compensation under the current system?

drgreg_181_1.input:
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."

cqs.cq: What if airlines changing flight schedules after passengers have confirmed their bookings causes significant inconveniences, such as extended travel times and disrupted plans, should airlines not be required to compensate passengers and provide satisfactory alternative arrangements?

Do you have any personal experience or data that supports the claim that airlines consistently prioritize their own interests over passenger convenience in the face of schedule changes, warranting a regulatory requirement for full reimbursement and alternative arrangements?

If airlines are allowed to alter flight schedules without consideration for passengers' plans, and require passengers to pay fees to make personal changes, why should passengers not have the same rights to compensation and accommodations when airlines change their schedules?
If airlines can profit from change fees from passengers, shouldn't they also be held accountable for the inconvenience and financial burdens caused by their own schedule changes?

elizwestley_222.input:
elizwestley: "A peanutfree table is less likely to have smears of peanut butter on/under it.
Risk of exposure is reduced
which is not as good as eliminated but is better than full exposure.
I see the parallel with these flight proposals.
Ban peanut products.
Yes, people will "sneak" them.
However, the risk will still be reduced over the nothing that we are doing now."

cqs.cq: If banning peanut products does not eliminate the risk of exposure, then why would the current measures of reducing the risk be deemed sufficient?

Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that banning peanut products would be more effective in reducing the risk of exposure than current measures, or is this a hypothetical assumption?

If a peanut-free table is less likely to have smears of peanut butter on/under it due to reduced exposure, would a school or public institution be more likely to have a student with a peanut allergy be exposed to peanuts if they have a "peanut-free" policy rather than a completely peanut-free policy?
If a peanut-free table is considered a safer option, then why would banning peanut products altogether not be seen as the ultimate solution to minimize exposure risk?

elizwestley_68.input:
elizwestley: "I've registered my son on a flight as peanutallergic and had the attendant try to hand him a bag of peanuts.
Flight personnel need more education on this."

cqs.cq: What if flight personnel's lack of proper allergy awareness and training causes them to provide incorrect information and potentially put the child's life at risk?
Do you think airline staff should receive comprehensive training on handling passengers with food allergies to prevent such incidents?

If flight attendants are trained to recognize and respond to peanut allergies, why would they not also be trained to recognize and respond to other common food allergies that could pose a life-threatening risk to passengers?
If flight attendants are trained to handle life-threatening situations, why can't they be trained to handle a life-threatening allergy like peanut allergies?

golff4fun_155.input:
golff4fun: "I think it's important to stress the real reason that aircraft is not returning to the gate.
Once the aircraft pulls away from the jetway, the crew is on the clock.
They are not being paid while sitting at a gate.
And 3 hours is too long to keep people on a grounded airplane."
 < this message is answering to > 
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: What if the prolonged ground time of aircraft, caused by delays, affects the crew's morale and job satisfaction, potentially leading to a higher risk of errors and accidents?

Do you have any experience or evidence to support the claim that deplaning during gate holds without CBP screening is a viable option for military members, considering the potential security risks and logistical challenges?
If the crew is expected to be paid while sitting at a gate, why should passengers be treated differently and forced to endure extended delays without compensation?
If passengers are allowed to deplane during gate holds, wouldn't this create a slippery slope where airlines could exploit this option to avoid paying crew members for extended periods of time?

golff4fun_162.input:
golff4fun: "Since weight seems to be the issue with charging extra fees for checked luggage,
the 98 lb person should pay less for a ticket than the 250 pounder.
I have thought that from the very beginning when the airlines introduced this new fee."
 < this message is answering to > 
NYCMuscleman18: "I know this sounds silly,
but I think I shouldn't be charged as much to check a bag as the 250lb man sitting next to me.
I don't mind getting weighed in public...
I don't know.
This is just something that seems unfair to lots of passengers,
and that probably won't get changed without regulation.
At the very least, DOT should make clear to airlines that they can discriminate on the basis of weight without fearing regulatory action."

cqs.cq: If the airline industry charges extra fees based on weight, does this potentially lead to a scenario where heavier individuals are unfairly penalized for their size, rather than being treated equally?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the weight of an individual is a reliable indicator of their airline ticket pricing?

If a 250-pound person pays the same fee for checked luggage as a 98-pound person, would it not be analogous to a second-generation American citizen of color being treated equally under the law as a white person?
If airlines are allowed to charge passengers differently based on weight, why should the 98 lb person be charged the same fee as the 250 lb person, who likely requires more resources and space?

grayk47__302.input:
grayk47: " you give an illegally (as in you stole it) acquired firearm to a friend to use responsibly
that person accidentally shoots someone
who should be blamed
Both should be held responsible
This is the same case for Snowden
he gave illegally acquired papers that he stole, to the Times in the hopes that they would responsible with it
They failed in that
a terrorist group was able to use the exposed information to alter their plans
It's cut and dry"

cqs.cq: If someone hands over illegally acquired information, can they still be held accountable for the consequences of its misuse by the recipient?

Does the principle of accountability and responsibility apply equally to individuals who provide information that contributes to harm, regardless of their intentions, just as it does in the case of the firearm's owner?

If a person who steals and gives a firearm to a friend, then that friend's accidental harm to another person is attributed to the original owner, why should the same logic not apply to Snowden's actions with the classified documents?

If a friend who receives a stolen firearm is held accountable for the consequences of its misuse, should the same accountability apply to Snowden for the consequences of the misuse of the information he stole?

hgranato_211.input:
hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,
I certainly empathize with the folks with peanut allergies.
That said, it seems arbitrary to ban peanuts and not tree nuts
given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)
and regulating all restaurants at airports as well?
Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: What if the burden of accommodating severe allergies is placed solely on the individual, does that not shift the responsibility away from the airline and onto the passenger, potentially affecting their ability to travel safely?

Do you have a scientific study or data that supports the claim that the likelihood of a severe reaction to tree nuts is indeed similar to peanuts, warranting a blanket ban of both in the context of airline safety?
If banning tree nuts due to a similar allergy risk is considered, would it not be logical to also ban other common allergenic foods like shellfish or dairy, given the potential severity of reactions?
If the airline industry can take precautions to accommodate passengers with peanut allergies, then why can't consumers take responsibility for their own allergies instead of relying on blanket bans?

howie_201.input:
howie: "First, stop reading that propaganda magazine.
Publications like that only serve to create fear in minds like yours.
Second, how old is your kid?
If under 5, relax the sensitivity will probably go away by the time he is 5.
Third, go to a real doctor  not an allergist and see if there is really even a problem at all.
This supposed plague of food allergies is the result of very clever advertising by this profession of pseudoscientists.
Allergists are not doctors.
I sincerely doubt you "know plenty of people who will die if they do have peanuts or breathe in peanut dust".
Almost noone is actually that allergic.
Lot's of people think they are much worse off than they really are.
Methinks you have an agenda.
Highly suspicious that the child of a physician who is hyper aware of bad things that can happen coincidentally has not one, but three life threatening allergies.
Have you heard of Munchasen by Proxy?
Do you realize that most kids have mild reactions to various food items that they invariably grow out of by the age of 5?
Food allergies have to be the most overblown imagined health problem of our time.
Hypochondriacs all."
 < this message is answering to > 
jsooudi: "I'm a physician, epidemiologist, and mother to a four year old boy with allergies to milk, peanuts and egg.
My son's dairy allergy is severe,
and he has had numerous lifethreatening anaphylactic reactions to trace amounts of milk,
which required multiple doses of epinephrine and trips to the Emergency Department.
Tests indicate that his peanut allergy is worse,
but fortunately he has only been exposed once to a peanut;
he put one in his mouth and had a relatively mild  reaction.
I've traveled with my children
and despite calling ahead, making requests, and reminding employees at the door, I've rarely had respect, let alone consistency, in any kind of peanutfree buffer zone or flight.
Several years ago Continental Airlines customer service headquarters informed me that they would serve peanuts on all flights as they were unable to guarantee a peanut free flight.
(So why not hand out weapons since they can't guarantee a weapon free flight either?)
I've sat with my epi pen in hand on a filthy flight with visible peanut crumbs on the floor while a flight attendant insisted on offering peanuts to the passengers around me because "it was their right."
Fortunately for me, my son's peanut allergy is not severe enough that it prohibits us from air travel.
Now that he is old enough to not put things in his mouth, and to protect himself, we are safer.
However, I know of many, many others in the allergy community, children and adults who simply can NOT fly.
My son's dairy allergy is quite severe.
The world would be a much safer place for us if no one consumed milk near him.
If his skin touches anything that once touched milk, even if it was partially cleaned, he will get severe hives.
If he consumes even less than a drop, within seconds his lips, eyes and face will swell, he will be covered in hives, vomit, and be gasping for breath.
Without epinephrine he would probably die within minutes.
But milk is ubiquitous,
and milk allergy relatively uncommon,
so we must protect ourselves.
Peanut allergy is common,
and it is a simple step to serve an alternative peanut based snacks for a short period of time.
So why is this a big problem?
The vast majority of potential reactions would be eliminated by simply avoiding snacks that have peanuts or peanut butter as an ingredient.
Peanut oil is known to contain very little of the actual peanut protein,
and would be of little risk in an airborne environment.
As a physician, I have responded to the call from airline staff asking for emergency medical assistance.
I am well aware of how expensive and inconvenient it is to ground a plane.
In addition, most epipens come in two pack doses,
each of which are good for maybe 10 to 15 minutes.
Which in a severe anaphylactic reaction is simply not enough time between the beginning of a reaction and the patient reaching EMS.
I've found that other passengers, as a rule, are extremely supportive,
and are more than happy to help with a fellow passengers safety.
I think the people commenting on this site would react entirely differently were they seated next to an allergic child on a plane.
Of course they would refrain from eating peanuts for a few hours if they knew it would hurt someone they were looking in the face.
But I am sympathetic to individuals who are unhappy with yet another discomfort inflicted on air travelers.
This restriction is designed to protect people with allergies from the airlines callous disregard for cleanliness and for our safety, not from our fellow passengers.
"Hi.  My name is Steven.  I am 4 years old.
I am allergic to peanuts, eggs and cow milk.
If I eat a peanut I'll get sick.
I ate a nut one time and got a big bump on my lip and it swelled up and it was hard to breathe.
It was scary and my dad gave me some medicine that made it better.
I would like for them to not give out peanuts so I won't get sick because I'm allergic.
Everybody should drink Sprite and eat Pringles and Pretzels.""

cqs.cq: What if the prevalence of peanut and dairy allergies is so severe that it necessitates the implementation of stringent safety measures in public spaces, such as airlines, to prevent life-threatening reactions, yet the public's perception of these allergies is often exaggerated or mild, suggesting a disconnect between reality and policy?

Do you, as a physician, have any evidence-based data or studies to support your claim that the vast majority of potential reactions to peanuts or peanut oil in an airborne environment are negligible, despite your personal anecdotal experience with your child?

If children like you, Steven, who have severe allergies are required to take precautions to avoid peanuts, why would the same precautions not be taken to avoid weapons on flights, considering the airlines' inability to guarantee a weapon-free flight?

If your son has indeed had severe reactions to trace amounts of milk and peanut, why do you not advocate for stricter airline protocols to completely eliminate the risk of peanuts on flights, rather than simply asking for a peanut-free buffer zone or flight?

howie_208.input:
howie: "Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from eating peanuts?
Didn't think so.
Most food allergies are imagined.
You clearly have a financial interest in promoting the myth of food allergy.
If someone is actually that allergic, they should stay home and not inconvenience the rest of us."
 < this message is answering to > 
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: Can the removal of peanuts from airlines, despite the potential risks, cause a significant increase in flight cancellations or operational disruptions that would outweigh the benefits of protecting those with life-threatening allergies?

Do you have any peer-reviewed studies or medical certifications that validate your claim that peanut residue can be life-threatening through contact or inhalation without a direct food consumption, or is this based on anecdotal evidence?

If a physician who has dedicated their career to helping people with food allergies is still advocating for a full ban on peanuts on airlines, should the industry and policymakers not be more inclined to prioritize the safety of passengers over convenience and profit?

If the airline industry is indeed prioritizing the safety of passengers, then why would a physician who has a clear financial interest in promoting the myth of food allergy be a credible advocate for a blanket ban on peanut products?

howie_213.input:
howie: "While I still dispute whether your reaction will be as severe as you believe, at least you realize that it is your responsibility to take precautions.
Your ailment is not shared by the general population,
and should not be an excuse to infringe upon the rights of others."
 < this message is answering to > 
hgranato: "As an adult with a severe tree nut allergy,
I certainly empathize with the folks with peanut allergies.
That said, it seems arbitrary to ban peanuts and not tree nuts
given the likelihood of a serious reaction is fairly similar.
