If the airlines could have precautions in place,
that would be a positive step.
However, supplying those items really should be the responsibility of the person with the allergy or, if it is a child, the caretaker.
Further, the logistics of implementing such a ban would be almost impossible.
Are we looking at searching passenger luggage, banning the sale of all foods with peanuts
(and since most carry the "made in a facility that also handles", you'd be looking at eliminating almost all foods)
and regulating all restaurants at airports as well?
Unfortunately, personal responsibility and proactive steps on the part of the person with the allergy is likely the only viable solution."

cqs.cq: What if the airlines' inability to provide adequate precautions would cause a higher risk of severe allergic reactions among passengers, potentially affecting the overall travel experience?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that individuals with allergies, such as tree nut allergies, should solely bear the responsibility for taking precautions, rather than expecting airlines or other entities to accommodate their needs?
If people with severe allergies are expected to take precautions, why should those with severe mental health conditions not be expected to do the same?
If the airlines can implement precautions to mitigate the risk of severe reactions, then why should the burden of responsibility for safety fall solely on the individual with the allergy?

howie_238.input:
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: Does the prevalence of perceived food allergies, such as the one you've described, influence airline policies on peanut restrictions?
Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that peanuts are "incredibly nutritious" when the general consensus among health organizations is that they are high in calories and fat?
If peanuts are indeed a nutritious and universally enjoyed food, why should they be removed from public spaces and flights for the sake of a perceived risk that is statistically negligible?

If peanuts are indeed so beneficial and safe, shouldn't we prioritize education over fear-mongering and instead teach people about responsible peanut consumption rather than perpetuating irrational fear and panic?

kateinhawaii_103.input:
kateinhawaii: "I personally have suffered from peanut allergies for over 40 years.
If there are packaged peanuts served on board a flight, it's 100% guaranteed that I will have a reaction from the peanut dust.
I do not agree with a buffer zone for a couple of reasons.
For me, it's the dust in the air.
Someone posted that the air circulates peanut dust right out of the air
but apparently not quick enough to prevent a life threatening reaction.
You know, airlines tried to create nonsmoking zones on airplanes but that didn't work either.
I have been on flights where nasty (and do I mean NASTY) flight attendants have made sarcastic remarks about me and my allergies especially on one Delta flight.
Northwest was great
because they respected their passengers enough to address their concerns
and prohibited peanuts altogether.
It was as much a relief to walk onto one of their flights as it was to walk onto one of the first smoke free flights!
Smokers use to use the same logic and reasoning to justify smoking on flights as these peanut proponents are using now.
I flew on many smoking flights and never needed to inject myself so that I could breathe
I can't say the same for flights with peanuts."

cqs.cq: If peanut dust circulation in the air can cause life-threatening reactions, should airlines prioritize passenger health over profit by prohibiting peanuts on flights altogether?

Do you have any evidence or scientific research that supports the claim that a buffer zone or a limited exposure to peanut dust on flights would not pose a significant risk to individuals with peanut allergies?

If people with peanut allergies can be guaranteed to have a reaction from the peanut dust in the air, why should airline passengers be exempt from the same consideration for their concerns about peanut-free zones?
If airlines can successfully implement buffer zones for smokers, then why can't they do the same for individuals with life-threatening allergies, like peanut allergies?

lauraclare_136.input:
lauraclare: "I have two children with potentially life threatening allergies to peanuts.
Unlike what one person commented, this is not a latest illness fad.
The latest research indicates that peanut allergy doubled in children from 1997 to 2002 and that number continues to increase.
It is one of the most deadly food allergies.
The presence of nuts on planes is a real fear.
While my kids have other potentially deadly food allergies,
peanuts pose a unique risk.
Nuts break into fine pieces with dust that can become airborne.
Peanut butter is sticky and gets wiped on seats and tray tables.
Even the slightest microscopic amount of nuts can create an anaphylactic reaction.
Although EpiPens can help,
they are not 100% effective
and should not be considered a solution to the risk peanuts pose to allergic individuals on planes.
Additional steroids, Benadryl shots, oxygen and other medical intervention may be necessary to stop an anaphylactic reaction.
EpiPens may need to be administered every 15 to 30 minutes as well.
People still die even with intervention.
Please help protect people by offering people the opportunity to get peanut free flights or ban the sale and serving of nut products on the planes."

cqs.cq: What if the lack of any of these safety measures, including the ban on nut products, causes a single anaphylactic reaction to result in a fatality on a plane?

Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that the presence of peanuts on planes poses a unique risk to children with peanut allergies, considering the numerous safety measures and protocols already in place to address anaphylactic reactions?
If a peanut allergy can pose a life-threatening risk to individuals on planes, why should the airline industry prioritize convenience over the safety and well-being of its passengers?
If peanut allergies are so deadly and EpiPens are not 100% effective, then why should the risk of peanuts on planes be considered less of a priority than the comfort of serving peanuts to passengers?

mcliverty_188_1.input:
mcliverty: "Lack of space should be at the top of the list of issues the airlines need to address.
Whenever you hear about new airliners (the big 300) they don't mention improved arm and leg room.
I can handle the commuters because typically you aren't on there long, but cross country is killer in those economy class seats.
If they were ergonomically designed and comfortable, maybe they would be better, but they are terrible for lumbar and leg support.
You could probably save space by using more comfortable materials that are slimmer in design.
Even the same leg room with a 3" wider seat would be great.
Maybe a pop up foot rest/block from the floor to rest your feet on..
Air travel has really just become a necessary evil you have to survive.
It's certainly not something enjoyed or eagerly anticipated any longer."

cqs.cq: What if the cramped seating and lack of ergonomic design in economy class cause passengers to experience chronic pain and discomfort, ultimately affecting their overall travel experience and airline reputation?

Do you have any data or studies that demonstrate how the current airline industry prioritizes passenger comfort over profit, considering the significant impact of ergonomic design on passenger satisfaction and overall experience?
If airline companies prioritize ergonomics and passenger comfort, would that not make air travel a more desirable experience rather than a necessary evil?
Should airlines prioritize passenger comfort over profit by investing in ergonomic designs and improved space for economy class seats?

mcliverty_188_2.input:
mcliverty: "I avoid it if I can and consolidate my trips whenever possible.
I would rather drive 1012 hours in my car than fly at this point.
I travel with my dog about twice a year.
Because he is 28 pnds, he has to be checked and travel in cargo.
It costs anywhere from $300400 round trip to take him.
I would rather be allowed to put him in a carrier that is secured by the seat belt and have him travel in the seat next to me (that I purchase a ticket for), especially if I have to pay the same or more for his ticket in cargo as I do for mine.
The cost and stress of handing him over to cargo is wearing me down and I will most likely not take him on some future trips so they will loose my business.
If the airlines could make their processes more customer & dog friendly, it would make travel much more enjoyable.
I'm sure my dog would behave as well or better than some humans in the cabin."

cqs.cq: What if the current airline policies cause a significant decrease in customer loyalty and revenue due to the restrictive pet travel options, ultimately affecting the airline's overall business performance?
Do you have any data or studies that demonstrate the significant financial and emotional burden of pet travel restrictions outweighs the airline's concerns about animal safety in the cabin?

If airlines can accommodate pets in the cabin for free or at a minimal cost, why can't they also provide similar accommodations for humans, especially considering the emotional and financial burdens it places on pet owners?
If airlines prioritize profits over passenger and pet convenience, then are they truly prioritizing customer experience, or just perpetuating unnecessary stress and costs?

mfball__143.input:
mfball: "we listen to the top five Democrats
the Republicans had the top eleven or so in their debate
Chafee seemed like a trainwreck in the debate
O'Malley did alright
You might be right about his chances at getting the nomination
some candidates' chances could be influenced greatly by the amount of media coverage they're getting
People were swearing up and down that Bernie didn't have a shot
no one had ever heard of him
Hillary was the only one getting airtime
now he's getting a lot of attention
 he's a competitive candidate
 I don't know a lot about O'Malley
nobody's been talking about him or interviewing him
I don't think he came off as a "sideshow" candidate in the debate
If he started getting more attention, I imagine he could probably pull numbers at least as good as the lowest of the Republicans that are still being talked about"

cqs.cq: What if the increased media coverage of O'Malley and Bernie Sanders significantly influences the voting decisions of undecided citizens, thereby affecting the overall outcome of the election?
Do you think the media attention and coverage that Bernie Sanders received before and after the debate influenced his relatively low initial polling numbers and subsequent rise in popularity?
If the media coverage and attention can significantly boost a relatively unknown candidate's chances, why does O'Malley's lack of media presence seemingly not be doing the same for his campaign?

If the media attention can influence a candidate's chances of getting the nomination, then how much impact would a lack of media attention have on the chances of a lesser-known candidate like O'Malley?

msrocker_127.input:
msrocker: "I agree with many others that even 3 hours is too long..
I think it should be 2
and should apply to all flights regardless of what airport, airline, destination, etc.
People are people no matter where they are
and should not be subjected to being miserable after paying a fee to fly somewhere!
Personally I have anxiety issues
and not being able to get out of an enclosed space is extremely stressful.
I think the airlines will now be forced to do all they can to prevent these delays.
Even though all will not be possible to prevent
I think there will be much less episodes wtih these new rules.
I think it goes a LONG ways to alleviate frustration
if we were informed in detail every 30 minutes.
I have been stranded on a plane 3 times
thankfully not more than 1 1/2 hours
but on one of these flights we were informed regularly along the way
and it made all the difference."

cqs.cq: What if the mandated 2-hour limit to prevent passenger anxiety issues causes airlines to increase flight delays, thus potentially offsetting the benefits of this new rule?

Do you have any evidence from airline industry experts or studies that suggests informing passengers every 30 minutes can actually alleviate frustration and reduce the number of flight delay episodes?

If the airline industry can provide detailed updates every 30 minutes to alleviate passenger frustration, why can't they also provide adequate compensation or accommodations to passengers who experience prolonged flight delays?

If people with anxiety issues are significantly stressed by being confined to an enclosed space, why should the proposed 3-hour limit for flight delays be universally applied, rather than allowing airlines to prioritize passenger comfort based on their individual needs?

secretcurse__137.input:
secretcurse: "Don't hold your breath for the Green Party Presidential Debate on any of our major news networks
a person that wants to run on the Green Party (or any other party) ticket absolutely has that right and should be able to express their views in public
there's no obligation to give them equal time on privately owned networks compared to the Democratic or Republican candidates that actually have a shot at winning the election
Clinton is extremely likely to win the Democratic nomination
Sanders has a shot at beating her
O'Malley, Webb, and Chafee are all sideshow candidates in the primary
just like the nominees from the Green, Libertarian, and Communist parties will be in the general election
Everyone should be allowed to express themselves in public places freely, but a cable news network isn't a public place"

cqs.cq: What if the exclusion of certain presidential candidates from major news networks causes their message to be ignored or diminished in the public sphere?
Do you believe the right to free speech and public expression should supersede the commercial interests of private media outlets in the context of a presidential election?
If major news networks are not obligated to provide equal time to the Green Party candidates, would they not also have the right to choose which other third-party candidates to feature or ignore?

If the Green Party has a right to participate in the presidential debate, why should privately owned networks not provide equal time for their candidates, considering they also have a right to free expression?

secretcurse__139.input:
secretcurse: "The first debate was already limited to five people
According to the FEC
171 people have officially declared their candidacy for the Democratic Party nomination with the FEC (sort by party to see the 171 people a bit easier)
Do you think every single one of the 171 people that have filed the paperwork with the FEC declaring their candidacy deserves their fair shot at expressing themselves at the first debate"

cqs.cq: Do you think the limited debate format would cause the 166 candidates who don't make the cut to have their voices and ideas suppressed?
Do you think the FEC's role in facilitating the candidacy process should prioritize the democratic process over the arbitrary limits set by the debate organizers?

If the 171 candidates who filed paperwork with the FEC are considered worthy of their chance to express themselves at the first debate, why would the 171 people who filed paperwork with the FEC not be considered worthy of their chance to express themselves at the first debate?
If the first debate is limited to five people, doesn't that imply that the rest of the 171 candidates who have filed with the FEC are being unfairly excluded from a platform to express their views?

smg_72.input:
smg: "It has become abundantly clear that commercial airline travel is a "race to the bottom" that satisfies needs of neither passengers nor airline profits.
A change of environment, which can only be imposed from outside the industry is needed.
Imposition of common sense regulations,
would level the playing field and remove the impetus for airlines to costcut in this area.
The results would be better service to customers and a renormalization of the playing field from which the airlines compete without fear of being undercut.
This goes for most of the proposed new regulations.
I sincerely believe that these regulations are in the best interests of both airlines and passengers."

cqs.cq: What if the imposition of common sense regulations by external entities would not be sufficient to level the playing field and improve customer service, but rather would only lead to further regulatory capture by the airlines, thereby undermining the intended benefits?

Do you have any empirical evidence from the airline industry that supports the notion that imposition of common sense regulations would uniformly benefit both airlines and passengers, rather than creating unintended consequences?

If the airline industry is considered a "race to the bottom" where regulations are needed to level the playing field, would this same logic not suggest that other industries, such as healthcare or education, also require similar external interventions to ensure fairness and quality?
If commercial airline travel has become a "race to the bottom," then does the industry's reliance on cost-cutting measures inherently compromise the safety and well-being of passengers?

smr_174_1.input:
smr: "The problem of whether to deplane or not is a tricky one.
On one side is the fact that sitting for an excessive amount of time is uncomfortable at best and unhealthy at worst.
However, on the other side there will be considerable time lost with the deplaning and reboarding.
One item which should be addressed is food and drink.
If the airline would normally have food for the passengers on that flight it seems silly to deny access to anything more than a bag of peanuts and a glass of water.
This happened to my husband last week on a Delta flight from Newark to Amsterdam.
The passengers were sitting on the plane for over six hours, at the gate,
but they were only offered one bag of peanuts and a glass of water or orange juice.
The plane eventually took off at approximately 1 a.m.,
when it should have taken off at 6.40 the previous evening."

cqs.cq: What if the airline's decision to limit food and drink options causes passengers to become irritable, affecting their overall experience and potentially leading to negative reviews and a loss of customer loyalty?

Do you have any evidence from airlines or industry experts that supports the claim that providing food and drinks to passengers during prolonged delays is a significant operational burden that outweighs the potential benefits to passenger comfort and satisfaction?
If passengers are required to wait for over six hours at the gate, why are they not entitled to the same standard of in-flight amenities as those who are actually flying?
If passengers are being denied basic amenities like food and drinks on long flights, can airlines justify the significant delays that cause passengers to miss their scheduled takeoff times?

smr_174_2.input:
smr: "The dinner was not served until the normal point in the flight, somewhere over the Atlantic!
Allowing passengers off the plane into a holding area would not give them access to food and drink,
but would let them move around.
However, when passengers expect food to be served on a flight they will often depend on that being served
and an excessive delay in serving meals could be hazardous to some people's health,
especially when on a connecting flight
so there has been no opportunity to purchase food and drinks at the airport."

cqs.cq: What if the delay in serving meals causes passengers to experience hunger-related health issues, potentially affecting their overall flight experience and satisfaction?

Does the airline's decision to delay meal service until the normal point in the flight and restrict access to food and drink in the holding area pose a greater risk to passengers' health than the potential benefits of allowing them to move around?

If passengers are required to wait for food on a flight, why would they not be given access to food and drink in the holding area, which would be more hygienic than allowing them to move around without sustenance?
If passengers are allowed to move around while waiting for their meal, why are they not provided with food and drink, which could be a more immediate and beneficial solution?

travellots_133_1.input:
travellots: "There should be no discrimination in how a passenger is bumped or compensated just because they may have paid less for a ticket or used frequent flyer miles.
Airline tickets are not lottery tickets.
One does not purchase a ticket hoping to reach a certain destination.
Same as if one pays $4 for a cup of coffee or $1, the cup is supposed to have coffee in it.
The price does not dictate that "maybe" you will get the product or service.
Also, the airline decides what prices or miles are used to purchase a promise to get you from point A to point B.
If they can not afford to give  a ticket for that price, they should not sell it.
When you reserve a ticket, the assumption is that you will be taken from point A to point B by the times given by the airline.
A passenger does not purchase a ticket just to see if maybe they can get somewhere because they have nothing better to do."

cqs.cq: If the airline industry is not a lottery where passengers pay for a chance to fly, then why do airlines often prioritize bumping passengers over refunding their tickets when they cannot afford to honor the service they sold?

Do you have any evidence from the airline industry or consumer protection laws that supports the claim that passengers who pay less for a ticket have a lesser right to be bumped or compensated than those who pay full price?

If airlines are required to honor the basic promise of a ticket, shouldn't they also be held accountable when their inability to deliver that promise results in passengers being bumped, regardless of the price paid?

If passengers are entitled to the service they paid for, why do airlines not guarantee the same level of compensation to all passengers, regardless of ticket price or frequent flyer miles, rather than leaving it to chance and arbitrary airline discretion?

travellots_133_2.input:
travellots: "If compensation is not high enough, the airlines will not have an incentive to schedule properly.
It is not fair to allow airlines to discriminate against lower fared passengers or "free" passengers
since it is the airline, not the passenger or government, who gave that passenger a seat.
Otherwise, airlines can advertise low fares or con you into using them to build up your "miles" and then always bump you for someone who paid more.
In away,it is the same as being able to increase your ticket price anytime after purchase.
When you are bumped, there are a lot of hidden extra costs
It irks me that airlines seem to be treating passengers more and more as if they have nothing better to do but wait around in airports and not get to where the airline promised to bring them.
Again, the airline sets the agreed price or miles for a seat, no one else.
The incentives to the airline should be to get all confirmed passengers (regardless of price paid) to the destination promised."

cqs.cq: What if airlines prioritize profit over passenger satisfaction, causing them to schedule flights in a way that affects the travel experience and overall trust in the industry?

Do you have any evidence that airlines, in fact, have a significant incentive to schedule properly and not prioritize higher-paying passengers over lower-paying ones, beyond the potential for increased revenue from ticket sales?
If airlines can artificially increase ticket prices after purchase, why can't passengers who paid more for their seats be prioritized over those who paid less?

If airlines are held accountable for their advertised promises, should they not also be incentivized to honor those promises for passengers of all fare classes, rather than prioritizing those who paid more?

zuclinator_125.input:
zuclinator: "I know Delta serves peanuts
as I travel to and from Detroit on Delta.
I was really surprised to learn this
as I didn't know until I was on the plane and in the air.
shouldn't they tell people before they pay for a flight?
Oh and the two row minimum around a person with a peanut allergy is a joke.
Someone with a peanut allergy is not going to be protected by that!"

cqs.cq: Should airlines inform passengers about potential allergens, such as peanuts, on their flights before ticket purchase, to ensure passenger safety and well-being?
Do you think Delta's lack of clear peanut allergy warnings before ticket purchase is a breach of their duty to inform and protect passengers with life-threatening allergies?

If airline companies are expected to provide clear warnings about peanuts on flights, why should they not also be required to inform passengers about the presence of peanuts before they purchase tickets?
If airlines inform passengers about in-flight meal options, should they not also disclose the presence of peanuts to passengers with life-threatening allergies before they purchase tickets?

TRUMP_114_1.input:
TRUMP: "we have been told through investigative reporting that he owes about $ 650 million to Wall Street and foreign banks
You learn a lot from financial disclosure
That I can tell you
you should go down and take a look at that
I 'm extremely underleveraged
The report that said $ 650
a lot of friends of mine that know my business
It 's not a lot of money relative to what I had
The buildings that were in question , they said in the same report , which was—actually , it was n't even a bad story , to be honest with you , but the buildings are worth $ 3.9 billion
the $ 650 is n't even on that
it 's not $ 650
It 's much less than that
I could give you a list of banks
I would—if that would help you , I would give you a list of banks
These are very fine institutions
very fine banks
I could do that very quickly
I am very underleveraged
I have a great company
I have a tremendous income
the reason I say that is not in a braggadocios way
It 's because it 's about time that this country had somebody running it that has an idea about money
we have $ 20 trillion in debt"

cqs.cq: What if the enormous amount of debt Trump claims to be underleveraged on, despite his assertions of wealth, ends up causing him to make decisions that prioritize short-term financial gains over long-term economic stability?
Do you have any evidence from reputable sources that supports your claim that you're "underleveraged" when your reported debt exceeds $650 million, while your assets are valued at $3.9 billion?

If a billionaire with a $3.9 billion asset portfolio claims to be "underleveraged" despite owing $650 million, wouldn't that indicate a significant disparity between his reported financial reality and the actual financial health of his business?

If you claim to be underleveraged, then how can you justify the fact that you have approximately $650 million in debts, considering your self-proclaimed success and your claim that you have a tremendous income?

TRUMP_114_2.input:
TRUMP: "our country 's a mess
it 's one thing to have $ 20 trillion in debt
Our airports are like from a third world country
You land at LaGuardia , you land at Kennedy , you land at LAX , you land at Newark , and you come in from Dubai and Qatar and you see these incredible—you come in from China , you see these incredible airports
we 've become a third world country
our bridges are good
everything 's in great shape
our airports
the worst of all things has happened
We owe $ 20 trillion
we 're a mess
We have n't even started
we 've spent $ 6 trillion in the Middle East
according to a report that I just saw
Whether it 's 6 or 5
 it looks like it 's 6
we could have rebuilt our country twice
it 's really a shame
it 's politicians like Secretary Clinton that have caused this problem
Our country has tremendous problems
We 're a debtor nation
We 're a serious debtor nation
we have a country that needs new roads , new tunnels , new bridges , new airports , new schools , new hospitals
we don't have the money
it 's been squandered on so many of your ideas"

cqs.cq: What if the country's current state of infrastructure decay and debt is a direct consequence of the politicians' lack of foresight and effective management, rather than a natural progression of events?

Do you have a credible source that supports the claim that the United States' current economic issues are solely the result of the actions of a single individual, such as Secretary Clinton, rather than a complex interplay of historical, systemic, and policy factors?

If the United States is considered a "third world country" due to its infrastructure and debt, would the same assessment be applied to a country like Haiti, which has also struggled with economic and infrastructure issues?

If our country's infrastructure is indeed in such a state of disrepair, then how can you justify the allocation of funds towards rebuilding our nation, when a significant portion of those funds were spent on the Middle East, rather than addressing our own domestic needs?

TRUMP_121_1.input:
TRUMP: "I do think it's time
it's all words
it's all sound bites
I built an unbelievable company
Some of the greatest assets anywhere in the world
real estate assets anywhere in the world
beyond the United States, in Europe, lots of different places
It's an unbelievable company
on occasion, four times, we used certain laws that are there
when Secretary Clinton talks about people that didn't get paid, first of all, they did get paid a lot, but taken advantage of the laws of the nation
if you want to change the laws, you've been there a long time, change the laws
you've been there a long time,
I take advantage of the laws of the nation
I'm running a company
My obligation right now is to do well for myself, my family, my employees, for my companies
that's what I do
what she doesn't say is that tens of thousands of people that are unbelievably happy and that love me"

cqs.cq: What if the emphasis on personal financial success and self-interest in Trump's statement causes his business decisions to negatively affect the lives of his employees and the broader community?

Do you have any evidence or scientific studies that support the claim that your business practices and personal obligations to "do well for myself, my family, my employees, and my companies" are more important than your responsibility to the broader public or societal well-being?
If Trump claims that he takes advantage of the laws of the nation to build his business, does that justify his actions when others, including his employees, are criticized for doing the same?

If Trump claims he built an "unbelievable company" with "real estate assets anywhere in the world" while admitting to using laws to his advantage, does that not undermine his claim of being a selfless business leader?

TRUMP_121_2.input:
TRUMP: "I'll give you an example
We're just opening up on Pennsylvania Avenue right next to the White House
if I don't get there one way, I'm going to get to Pennsylvania Avenue another
we're opening the Old Post Office
I'm a year ahead of schedule
that's what this country should be doing
We build roads
they cost two and three and four times what they're supposed to cost
We buy products for our military
they come in at costs that are so far above what they were supposed to be
we don't have people that know what they're doing
When we look at the budget, the budget is bad to a large extent
we have people that have no idea as to what to do and how to buy
The Trump International is way under budget
way ahead of schedule
we should be able to do that for our country"

cqs.cq: What if the lack of transparency and accountability in the budgeting process, as highlighted by Trump, cause inefficiencies that ultimately affect the nation's ability to effectively manage public projects and allocate resources?

Can you explain how the successful management of the Trump International project, which you cited as a model for government projects, compares to the management of other high-profile infrastructure projects that have been criticized for their cost overruns and delays?

If the Trump Organization can successfully execute a project like the Trump International under budget and ahead of schedule, why can't the federal government do the same with the budget and infrastructure projects that it oversees?

If the Trump International project is a successful example of efficient construction and management, why can't the federal government replicate that same level of performance and accountability in its own projects and procurement processes?

TRUMP_125_1.input:
TRUMP: "Secretary Clinton doesn't want to use a couple of words, and that's law and order
If we don't have it, we're not going to have a country
when I look at what's going on in Charlotte, a city I love, a city where I have investments, when I look at what's going on throughout various parts of our country, whether it's—I mean, I can just keep naming them all day long
I just got today the, as you know, the endorsement of the Fraternal Order of Police, we just—just came in
We have endorsements from, I think, almost every police group, very—I mean, a large percentage of them in the United States
We have a situation where we have our inner cities, African- Americans, Hispanics are living in hell
it's so dangerous
You walk down the street, you get shot
In Chicago, they've had thousands of shootings, thousands since January 1st
I'm saying, where is this
Is this a war-torn country
What are we doing
we have to stop the violence
In a place like Chicago, where thousands of people have been killed, thousands over the last number of years
almost 4,000 have been killed since Barack Obama became president"

CLINTON_1_1.input:
CLINTON: "The central question in this election is really what kind of country we want to be and what kind of future we 'll build together
Today is my granddaughter 's second birthday
I think about this a lot
we have to build an economy that works for everyone , not just those at the top
we need new jobs , good jobs , with rising incomes
I want us to invest in you
I want us to invest in your future
jobs in infrastructure , in advanced manufacturing , innovation and technology , clean , renewable energy , and small business
most of the new jobs will come from small business
We also have to make the economy fairer
That starts with raising the national minimum wage and also guarantee , finally , equal pay for women 's work
I also want to see more companies do profit-sharing"

cqs.cq: What if prioritizing jobs in infrastructure, advanced manufacturing, innovation, and clean energy ends up causing a surge in labor costs that would negatively affect the competitiveness of small businesses, thereby hindering their ability to create the jobs that CLINTON claims are essential for a better future?

Can you provide evidence from your own experience or public records that you, as a politician, have actually implemented or supported policies that directly benefit the working class and not just middle-class individuals?
If a country's economic growth is solely driven by the interests of the top 1%, does that not undermine the notion of a future built for everyone, as Clinton suggests?

If the economy is supposed to work for everyone, why does the Clinton's economic plan primarily focus on jobs and investments for the top and not the grassroots that are the backbone of small businesses?

TRUMP_99.input:
TRUMP: "I will release them as soon as the audit
I 've been under audit almost for 15 years
I know a lot of wealthy people that have never been audited
I said , do you get audited
do you get audited
I get audited almost every year
in a way , I should be complaining
I 'm not even complaining
I do n't mind it
It 's almost become a way of life
I get audited by the IRS
But other people don't
We have a situation in this country that has to be taken care of
I will release my tax returns—against my lawyer 's wishes—when she releases her 33,000 e-mails that have been deleted
As soon as she releases them , I will release
I will release my tax returns
that 's against—my lawyers
they say , `` Do n't do it . '' I will tell you this
No—in fact , watching shows , they 're reading the papers
Almost every lawyer says , you do n't release your returns until the audit 's complete
When the audit 's complete , I 'll do it
I would go against them if she releases her e-mails"

cqs.cq: Would releasing his tax returns before the audit is complete compromise his ability to negotiate the terms of the audit and potentially reveal sensitive information about his financial dealings?
Do you have a tax professional or accountant who can verify that releasing tax returns during an ongoing audit is not a standard practice, contrary to what your lawyers claim?
If the IRS audits the president, why should the public not have access to the president's tax returns until the audit is complete?

If tax returns are considered private and confidential, then shouldn't Trump's lawyers' advice to wait until the audit is complete be more relevant than his claim that he would release his returns as soon as his lawyer releases her e-mails?

TRUMP_174_1.input:
TRUMP: "I would love to respond
I got to watch in preparing for this some of your debates against Barack Obama
You treated him with terrible disrespect
I watched the way you talk now about how lovely everything is and how wonderful you are
It does n't work that way
You were after him
you were trying to—you even sent out or your campaign sent out pictures of him in a certain garb , very famous pictures
I do n't think you can deny that
just last week , your campaign manager said it was true
when you tried to act holier than thou , it really does n't work
as far as the lawsuit , yes , when I was very young , I went into my father 's company , had a real estate company in Brooklyn and Queens , and we , along with many , many other companies throughout the country—it was a federal lawsuit—were sued
We settled the suit with zero—with no admission of guilt
It was very easy to do
I notice you bring that up a lot"

cqs.cq: Does the fact that Trump's campaign manager acknowledged the use of the infamous picture of Obama allegedly wearing a garb influence the perception of his claims of being holier than thou?
Can you provide a credible source that substantiates the claim that your father's company was sued and settled with no admission of guilt?
If a politician's past actions and public image are scrutinized for their potential biases, why should Trump's past campaign tactics and personal character not be held to the same standard?
If Trump claims that his past business dealings were unfairly targeted, why does he not hold similar standards for his own campaign's use of controversial images of Obama?

TRUMP_112.input:
TRUMP: "That was more than a mistake
That was done purposely
That was not a mistake
When you have your staff taking the Fifth Amendment , taking the Fifth so they 're not prosecuted
when you have the man that set up the illegal server taking the Fifth
it 's disgraceful
this country thinks it's—really thinks it 's disgraceful , also
As far as my tax returns , you do n't learn that much from tax returns"

cqs.cq: What if the President's willingness to take the Fifth Amendment and the actions of those around him being shielded from prosecution, does not set a precedent that undermines the integrity of the justice system and affect the public's trust in the government?
Do you have a credible source that supports the claim that the president's personal tax returns are not indicative of their overall character or leadership capabilities?

If Trump's staff taking the Fifth Amendment to avoid prosecution is considered a sign of a country's dysfunction, why is his own use of the Fifth Amendment in response to questions about his tax returns not seen as equally concerning?
If the President considers taking the Fifth Amendment to be a sign of guilt, then does he believe that his own actions, which he described as "done purposely", are also indicative of guilt?

CLINTON_244_1.input:
CLINTON: "let me start by saying , words matter
they really matter when you are president
Words matter when you run for president
I want to reassure our allies in Japan and South Korea and elsewhere that we have mutual defense treaties and we will honor them
It is essential that America 's word be good
I know that this campaign has caused some questioning and worries on the part of many leaders across the globe
I 've talked with a number of them
I want to—on behalf of myself , and I think on behalf of a majority of the American people , say that , you know , our word is good
It 's also important that we look at the entire global situation
There 's no doubt that we have other problems with Iran
personally , I 'd rather deal with the other problems having put that lid on their nuclear program than still to be facing that
Donald never tells you what he would do
Would he have started a war ?
Would he have bombed Iran ?"

cqs.cq: Does the president's commitment to honoring mutual defense treaties with allies have a more significant impact on global stability than the president's hypothetical actions in hypothetical scenarios?

Can you provide any evidence that the United States' reputation as a trustworthy nation has been a significant factor in international diplomacy and alliances, rather than just a rhetorical device in your presidential campaign?
If the United States can honor its defense treaties with Japan and South Korea, why would it not be expected to honor its own commitments to the Indigenous people, who were here first?

If the reliability of the US word is so crucial to global stability, why does Clinton's campaign rhetoric of a "good word" seem to be undermined by his administration's record of bombing and invading countries, such as Iraq and Libya?
